references: Our xLSTM-TS model adapts the xLSTM for time series forecasting by using the xLSTMBlockStack and adjusting key parameters to optimise performance while managing computational constraints. Inspired by the official xLSTM implementation, we modified it for a time series-specific approach. The detailed architecture of the xLSTM-TS model is summarised in Table IV.

S3.T5.1.table:
Parameter Value
Input Size 1
Embedding Dimension 64
Output Size 1
Sequence Length 150
Batch Size 16
Context Length 150
references: Key configuration settings are listed in Table V. The input size was set to 1, representing the number of features in the time series (in this case, the closing price). An embedding dimension of 64 was chosen to balance memory usage and performance. The output size was also set to 1, indicating that the model predicts the next value in the series (the next day or hour). A sequence length of 150 was used to capture sufficient historical data without incurring excessive computational cost. The batch size was set to 16 to avoid GPU memory limits. The context length was aligned with the sequence length to ensure consistency in data fed into the model.

S3.T6.1.table:
Parameter Value
Convolutional Kernel Size 4
Projection Block Size 2
Number of Heads 2
references: The configurations for the mLSTM and sLSTM blocks are detailed in Tables VI and VII, respectively.

references: The configurations for the mLSTM and sLSTM blocks are detailed in Tables VI and VII, respectively.

S3.T10.1.table:

Number of Stacks 10

references: To balance learning complex features with computational efficiency, the parameters outlined in Table X were chosen.

S3.T11.1.table:
Parameter Value
Hidden Size 64
LSTM Layers 1
Number of Attention Heads 4
Dropout 0.1
references: TFT processes static covariates, past observed inputs, and known future inputs through embedding layers. The LSTM layer captures short-term dependencies, with a hidden size of 64 ensuring sufficient capacity to learn intricate patterns. The multi-head attention mechanism with four heads enables the model to focus on multiple aspects of the input data simultaneously, capturing long-term dependencies and interactions between different time steps. Gating layers, including Gated Residual Networks (GRNs), control the flow of information and suppress irrelevant parts of the network, allowing the model to adjust its complexity based on the dataset. The key configuration parameters for the TFT model are outlined in Table XI.

S4.T12.1.table:
Parameter Value
Learning Rate 0.0001
Batch Size 16
Sequence Length 150
Number of Epochs 200
Patience 30
Gradient Clipping Max Norm 1.0
Optimiser Adam
Loss Function MSE
references: The final configuration, as detailed in Table XII, provided the best trade-off between computational efficiency and prediction accuracy. This thorough tuning process ensured that the xLSTM-TS model was well-suited for time series forecasting tasks, demonstrating robust performance across the chosen datasets.

The models were trained with denoised data and tested on the original datasets to evaluate their performance. The predicted values were compared with the actual test set values, and the performance metrics are shown in Table XV.
